text: coming out of a place like Google where
I used to work we felt like
infrastructure was our advantage and to
see that we we could take that advantage
that we felt like we had which is
proprietary and now have something
available to us as a start-up that put
us on a level playing field with a
company like Google was really what
attractiveness to come in and start
using AWS but into not quite working
next door in the systems architect my
name is Prakash Janek Karaman from next
door calm and I'm the company's
co-founder and chief marketing so next
door is a private social network through
neighborhood its goal is to bring
communities together whether those
communities want to talk about
neighborhood events crime and safety
sell or buy things or kittens away
they're all the things that are
important in neighborhoods but often
hard to do when you don't know your
neighbors so our goal is to connect we
use almost 30 different services are
provided by uwx
whereas at the very beginning we were
only using ec2 and s3 now we're using
ECS we're using redshift we're using RDS
for load balancers we're using the whole
stack early on we didn't have a solid
feel for exactly what kind of
infrastructure you need but
launch things from and terminate them
when they need it anymore and the
overhead of building and infrastructure
ourselves a lot of it in general the
benefit of AWS over a shared hosting
provider was that AWS afforded as a
level of flexibility that we didn't have
with shared hosting we could try
multiple things in parallel without
concern for having to over provisioning
resources it allows us to move as fast
as the industry and encourages us to do
that which keeps things new and fresh
and clean and interesting to our
developers but also cost-effective for
running business when we think about
infrastructure at next one one things
that we want it to be is completely
invisible and transparent our developers
so we don't spend a lot of time thinking
about what the underlying machines look
like or what the underlying resources
look like developers can think about
what their requirements are to launch
new products and we provide that
infrastructure to them transparently the
value for us is that we are never held
back by the way systems and services
we're constantly able to build new
things get revealed things that we don't
have to maintain or support notes will
not track down whether we know where our
core competencies is developing great
products for users it's not managing
thousands of machines and managing and
provisioning lots and lots of hardware
and lots of lots of esoteric services we
want to be able to use those services at
our disposal to assemble great problems
and so for companies that are building
products it seems like the best idea is
leave the infrastructure for the guys
who know how to manage that and get back
to what you're doing well which is
building great products
